bboxes.raw_text:
A field licensing crewfrom the
Veterinary Center of the Mari
copa County Health Department
has begun checking door to door
for unVaccinated and unlicensed
dogs, according to DR.. S. F.
Farnsworth, director. Dog Ii
censes we're due on January l,
1864 and owners who do not now
have their dogs licensed are in
violation of state law.


DR.. Farnsworth explained that
all dogs four months of age must
be licensed, and that dogs must
be vaccinated against rabies be-
fore a license can be purchased.
The license fee is $3.50.


In order to obtain license
the owner must have the dog vac
cinated and the veterinarian will
give information on the purchase
of license. If, however, the dog
has a current vaccination and the
owner received anIBMform from
the Veterinary Center, he can
simply mail it in with a check
for $3.50.


Citations will be issued to those
who fail to comply with Vaccina-
tion and licensing requirements.


"Rabies is a serious, and in
creasing problem in Arizona
DR.. Farnsworth emphasized.
During 1868 there we're 90 lab
oratory diagnosed cases of rabies
in domestic and wildlife animals;
ii of these cases occurred right
here in Maricopa County. How
ever, there we're no cases OF
rabies in dogs in this county,
though there we're % in the state.
Eight of Maricopa County cases
occurred in bats; the other three
we're in a bobcat and two in
domestic cats. The only possible
way we can prevent rabies in
domestic animals and the human
population is through a stringent
program of vaccination and Ii
censing of dogs.


rabies is an incurable di-
sease. Once symptoms appear
all of medical science is power
less in curing it. Death is inevi-
table. 1t is the responsibility of
everyone to help prevent this
dread disease"

CARPETS INSTALLED and re-
paired Days, evenings, Sundays
Call 275-3O53.

HARTFORD 1.-THE key to
employment today, more than
ever before, is education and
training. There are today in the
nations work force between 2
and 8 million more people I'M
prepared for skilled jobs than
there are unskilled jobs avail
able. With unemployment run
ming consistently around 4 mil
lion people, it takes no mathe-
NAUTICAL genius to see that here
in lies our unemployment prob
lem"


Pointed out by Arthur A Chap
in, Special Assistant to the Sec
rotary of Labor, in an address
before the Association for the
Study of Negro Life and History.


To-day" he said, refusal
to hire a man just because Of his
race or color occurs in fewer
and fewer places, fewer times.
Job opportunities are opening up
rapidly" He added that this
leaves us with the ironical fact
that those who didn't get the edu-
cation and training to do skilled
work have lost their unskilled
jobs to machines. "They are
now unprepared for the skilled
jobs which are suddenly open to
Them"


eff every trace of racial pref
udice could be magically removed
from every American mind to-
night" MIR. Chaplin continued,
tomorrow would be free of dis
elimination, but the Negro would
still be shackled by the disad-
vantage of a century of poor edu-
cation and training. To really be-
lieve in equal employment OPP
portunity is to recognize thatre-
moval of prejudice is only one of
three necessary steps. The other
two are training and increas-
ing the number of Jobs for every
body. 1t won't do any good to
take down the signs that read
Whites Only if they are re-
placed by other signs reading
mo Vacancy as Labor Secre-
tary Writ has pointed OUT


MIR. Chaplin noted that thou
sands of Negro men and women
are now being trained atGovern-
ment expense under the Area
Redevelopment Act and the Man
power Development and Training
Act. He told of experimental
projects of the Labor Depart
ment's Bureau of Employment
Security under which training
is being given in the basic lit
erary skills--the three RS
to prepare the disadvantage for
training.

Arizona ranked 30th in total
1868 fall enrolment at institu-
tions of higher learning, above
such states as Alabama, Ne
braska, West Virginia and YER
mont. (Arizona is 34th in7popu-
lation size).

STATE IS 3Ofh
IN SCHOOL RANK

tions of higher learning, above

braska, West Virginia and YER
mont. (Arizona is 34th in7popu-
